724041f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - Thompson Street
724041f-a.text:
Washington Square South, east from Thompson Street to West Broadway. 58 Washington Square South is the old frame on the corner of Thompson Street. This, with the three small buildings adjoining on Thompson Street, and the two 4-story houses 59-60 Washington Square,are shortly to be demolished. The vacant lot will be fenced about, and later uses for tennis courts.
June, 1925.
724041f-a.folder: Washington Square South & Thompson Street, Manhattan, NY

723990f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Thompson Street
723990f-a.text:
Art Exhibition, Washington Square South at the S.E. corner of Thompson Street, seen from Thompson Street, with the Washington Arch, 11-13 Washington Square North, and the One Fifth Avenue apartment hotel, in the background.
The vacant lot results from the demolition of 58 (the old frame house) and 59-6O Washington Square South, about 1927. It will later be used for tennis courts.
This outdoor art exhibition is an annual Greenwich Village event.
May 28, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
723990f-a.folder: Washington Square & Thompson Street, Manhattan, NY

724034f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - Thompson Street
724034f-b.text:
Washington Square Park: The circle and Arch as viewed northward from Washington Square South (foreground, car tracks thereon) at Thompson Street and showing on the far side of the Park several 3 1/2-story homes that bear Nos. 13 to 9 Washington Square North. They are the property of the Sailors Snug Harbor Corporation and are east of Fifth Ave.; a thoroughfare that begins at that point. Upon the latter appears the towered apartment house; known as No. 1 Fifth Ave. This is a set of
3 similar views, at different dates.
May 23, 1933.
View 2:eMay 22, 1935.
View 3:-September 26, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
V1eW ~E NWEG ~ E72S
724034f-b.folder: Washington Square South & Thompson Street, Manhattan, NY

723517f-a.title: Manhattan: Thompson Street - Washington Square South
723517f-a.text:
248 to 240 Thompson Street and 55, 59 Washington Square South, at, adjoining, and south of the S.E. corner, shortly before the demolition of these buildings. No. 58 Washington Scuare South, at the corner, and No. 246 Thompson Street, the next door but one below it, are old frame houses. See also Washington Square. No. 240 is the one-story garage adjoining the seven-story building (which will not be torn down) at the N.E. corner of West 3rd Street.
August 25, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
723517f-a.folder: Thompson Street & Washington Square South, Manhattan, NY

724045f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - Thompson Street
724045f-b.text:
(1)
Judson Memorial Baptist Church and other buildings, Washington
Square South, from Thompson to Sullivan Streets.
This church, with the 7-story tower, was erected in 1892, on the site where a coal-yard had stood in the 1850's. The buildings in the middle of the block, including the rooms in the tower were the Judson Hotel, one of the three Knott hotels on the Square; but they are now a New York University dormitory.
May 5, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, three weeks later. Notice how the leaves on the
trees have come out.
May 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A more inclusive view, across the Park.
December 24, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.  )
L1
724045f-b.folder: Washington Square South & Thompson Street, Manhattan, NY
